title-group.article-title: FRACTURED LIFE AND THE AMBIGUITY OF HISTORICAL TIME: BIOPOLITICS IN AGAMBEN AND ARENDT

bio.p: Anthony Curtis Adleris associate professor of German and comparative literature at Yonsei University in South Korea.

abstract.p: Examining Agamben's reception of Hannah Arendt, and especiallyThe Human Condition, in his theorization of biopolitics, this essay argues thatHomo Sacer I, by identifying Arendt with a quasi-Straussian “political philosophy,” fails to acknowledge the complexity of her conception of history. Far from simply affirming the normative force of classical political categories, Arendt regards these as emerging from a living power of distinction that thinking, by showing the historical process that brings about the effacement of these distinctions, seeks to bring into view. Nevertheless, Arendt's conception of history is not without contradiction: while arguing that metaphysics went astray by subordinating praxis to poiesis, her very account of history suggests that this subordination is inevitable, since only a “poetic,” indeed violent, act of making a distinction can distinguish praxis from poiesis. Precisely this problem lies at the center of Agamben's early engagement with Arendt inThe Man without Content.

ref.mixed-citation: In a 2004 interview, Agamben remarked, “I see my work as closer to no one more than to Foucault” (de la Durantaye, 209). And in an interview with Abu Bakr Rieger, he states, “There is no great theoretical difference between my work and Foucault's; it is merely a question of the length of the historical shadow” (246).

The transliterated spellingszoē(used by Agamben, with an accent mark over the eta in the Italian edition) andzōē(used by Arendt) are dialectical variations of the same Greek word and do not correspond to any semantic difference. In citing both authors, I have retained the form that appears in the text cited. Elsewhere I have decided, following Arendt, to usezōē, since this is the first spelling given in Liddell-Scott's Greek-English lexicon.

While Arendt's theorization of totalitarianism and the concentration camps is also important for the project ofHomo Sacerespecially the third part of the first volume, Agamben distinguishes this from her contribution to a biopolitical perspective per se.

See also Arendt
1958,313n76.
Here, of course, we detect the influence of Benjamin's “Critique of Violence.” Cf. Agamben 1998,63–67.
For a critique of Arendt's concept of society, see Pitkin, Benhabib, and Bernstein.

See Agamben
1998,38. For a succinct, largely affirmative analysis of the biopolitical moment in Arendt, see Duarte.

The relationship betweenzōē, “bare life” (in Italian,vita nuda)—in essence a translation of Benjamin'sblosses Leben—and Arendt's “biological life” is complex. The differences between them are sometimes exaggerated and misunderstood. In the introduction toHomo SacerI, they are used more or less synonymously, but as the argument progresses, a more differentiated sense of “bare life” emerges: thus in the third of the three “provisional conclusions” that introduce the final “threshold,” “bare life” is understood as the “originary political element” that is produced through the “fundamental activity of sovereign power,” and as the “threshold of articulation between nature and culture,zoēandbios” (Agamben 1998, 181). In this sense, Arne De Boever is also right to speak of it as a “third term” introduced alongsidezōēandbios. Yet the difference is really one of perspective rather than referential value: bare life, as the “threshold” of articulation betweenzōēandbios, is the point at which the distinction collapses into in-distinction and hence can be grasped in its genesis as distinction. But, for the Greeks,zōēis essentiallyindistinct lifeandbiosdistinct, qualified forms of life. Bare life is not something fundamentally different fromzōēbut iszōēconceived in its structural relation—unthinkable to the Greeks—tobiosand to the political.Zōē, one might say, is in-distinction thought from the perspective of distinction (ofeternal ideas or forms); bare life is in-distinction thought from the perspective of in-distinction.Biological life, in a similar fashion, corresponds tozōēbut also takes on the sense ofbare life, emerging as the perspective from whichlifebecomes thinkable as a unitary process that producesbiosout of itself. Biological life becomes the way of thinking all forms of life in their emergence.

See Agamben
1998,27.

Against the dominant tendency to see an affinity between Arendt's project and the political philosophy of Leo Strauss, Miguel Abensour (2006) maintains that Arendt resists both the scientification of politics and the turn to political philosophy.

As Paul Ricoeur explains, she seeks to establish norms through which to “judgethe eclipse of politics as the supreme expression of free action and tocondemnall the attempts to dissolve politics into human engineering” (50).
See Edkins.

In The Man without Content , Agamben explores the meaning and etymology of the Greekepochē, understanding it in terms of the double sense of holding back and presenting/offering, and then suggests translating it as “rhythm” (100). This relates to thekatechonof Paul's second epistle to the Thessalonians: “something that slows and delays the advent of the Messiah” (Agamben 1999a, 114). Of interest in this context is Agamben's discussion of the “Catechontic” dimension of both Carl Schmitt and Erik Peterson (2011a,6–8).

Arendt was certainly aware, as Agamben also notes, that the Latinvitaactually comprises bothbiosandzōē. Given this, it is perhaps all the more significant that she reserves the English “life” (or GermanLeben) to signify the concept of life in the most encompassing sense.

Arendt identifiesLebensphilosophieprincipally with Nietzsche and Bergson, but she also suggests their proximity to Marx. Indeed, she speaks of “life and labor philosophers” in the same breath (cf. Arendt 1958, 172), and then, in an important footnote, actually refers to all three together as “[t]he greatest representatives of modern life philosophy” (313n76).
Agamben beginsHomo SacerI with an account of this fracture (1).

It is significant, in this regard, that, as Agamben observes,zōēcan accept comparative adjectival qualifications, such aszōē aristē kai aidios(“a more noble and eternal life”)—it can havedifferentqualities predicated or attributed to it—and yet one does not sayzōē politikēbutbios politikos. This suggests not only, as Agamben observes, that “simple, natural life” is excluded from the polis but thatzōēcannot be qualified in such a way as to establish different, substantively distinct regions of life.Zōēlikewise does not allow pluralization (1998,1–2).
For Agamben, as Adam Thurschwell notes, “politics is nothing but philosophy”: the constitutive structures of politics and metaphysics are one and the same (173).

Vatter (2006) suggests that Arendt's crucial invocation of “natality” inThe Human Conditionmust be situated within biopolitics. It is indeed quite curious, as Vatter notes, that readers of Arendt have paid so little attention to the link between the affirmative characterization of natality, which plays a fundamental role in the structure of action, and the critique of merely “biological life.”
For a brief but provocative discussion of the significance of “surplus” for biopolitical theory, see Vatter (2009).

Many commentators have observed Arendt's delight in making distinctions (Benhabib, 123–24). Yet Arendt's “art of making distinctions,”I would argue, does not so much involve, as for Benhabib, “phenomenological essentialism”—the “belief, particularly prominent inThe Human Condition , that each type of human activity has a proper ‘place’ in which it can be carried out”—but performance: an enactment of the power of biological life to generate distinctions from out of its in-distinction through self-transcendence.

There is no mention inThe Human Conditionof Dilthey, who appears in Heidegger'sBeing and Timeas the principal representative ofLebensphilosophie(1979, 46–47). For Heidegger, the problem withLebensphilosophieis not so much the privilege it grants to life as its failure to interrogate the being of life. For Heidegger, indeed, philosophy stands in so close a relation to life that the termLebensphilosophieis a pleonasm—as redundant as the “botany of plants.”
Martin Jay, in his account of Hannah Arendt's dependence on existentialism, is right to stress the “decisionist” and ultimately Nietzschean tendencies in Arendt.
This, of course, recallsBeing and Time , where death is understood as the “eigenste, unbezügliche, unüberholbare Möglichkeit” (Heidegger1979,250).
We recall Heidegger's characterization of Nietzsche's thought as a “reversed Platonism”(1961, 1:188).
We may find an explicit model in Nietzsche: in theBirth of Tragedy , his account of the tragic death of tragedy makes it possible to think its Wagnerian rebirth.
I would thus contest de la Durantaye's claim that Arendt's influence on Agamben only began to figure prominently in his writings in the early 1990s (207).
The first essay inNudities, published in Italian in 2009, could be seen as an attempt to again join together these two historical narratives and establish their inner unity (Agamben2011b,1–10).
Arendt conceives of genius, in contrast, as the attempt ofhomo faberto achieve the equivalent of action and speech. The ascent of labor itself brings an end to the age of genius (1958,210).
In the 1988–89 essay prefacing the new edition ofInfancy and History, Agamben seeks to establish continuity between his earlier work and the emerging project of his mature philosophy.

Ernesto Laclau calls attention to the utopian aspect of Agamben's thought, arguing that this precludes the possibility of meaningful political interventions (22). Negri suggests, against Agamben's alleged utopianism, the need for a practical yet transformative and revolutionary engagement with the system of production as it exists (124).
